column3: Gotta say, visiting Nest and having Fadell explain it to me before it was public was one of the more fun things I've done as a journalist.
"Together, we've changed the conversation about the connected home."--Nest's Tony Fadell
Fadell is recapping Nest's history and accomplishments. http://t.co/IJihgvYxFF
Here's Tony Fadell, who says Nest has a bunch of updates today. http://t.co/HwWFD0TSTm
@MartinSFP Is yours also starting in nine minutes?
@MartinSFP Not that they told me.
@davezatz I find it fascinating how very separate Google is keeping the two brands.

Astro Teller says getting Glass into the world early was the right thing to do. But Google should have been clearer that it was a prototype.
Astro Teller on failing fast: "Anyone who can find a reason why we're on the wrong track is going to be the superhero of the month for us."
A Google self-driving car dealt just fine with an elderly woman in an electric wheelchair chasing a duck in the middle of the road.
Google X has had people hide in canvas bags in the middle of the road and jump out, just to see how a self-driving car would react.
So Google X is sending its self-driving cars to San Francisco, where driving on those hilly, congested streets is more challenging.
Now Google self-driving cars "drive 10,000 miles a week in Mountain View, and nothing happens...We need more negative examples."
Google X then concluded that humans weren't good backup systems for self-driving cars, and built cars with no steering wheel at all.
But it learned that humans were terrible at dealing with being behind the wheel of self-driving cars, and ended the test.
In 2012, Google X was so happy with its self-driving Lexuses that it gave them to non-X Googlers to try for their real commutes, as a test.
Astro Teller: "When we started, we couldn't possibly know the 10,000 things we would have to do for a car to drive itself really well."
Google X staffers also tested Loon balloons' strength by line dancing on them in different types of socks: normal ones, and fluffy ones.
Astro Teller: In refining its Loon balloons, Google X looked at other thin, leak-resistant things: Doritos bags, sausage casings, condoms.

10) Try to avoid reading a message and not taking action on it (this is hard to do)
9) Archive, archive, archive
8) Use the amazing, life-changing The Email Game to blast through hundreds of messages as fast as possible
7) Use something like Gmail with good spam protection and features like Priority Inbox
6) Program keyboard macros to help you send common replies ("that doesn't fall into my area of coverage") without typing them every time
5) Make most responses polite and clear, but very brief
4) Do try to respond relatively quickly to non-irrelevant messages sent by actual humans, in part so they don't feel the urge to follow up
3) If someone sends you an absurdly irrelevant message, it's reasonable to filter that person out of your inbox henceforth
2) Use rules to filter out automated messages you never asked for in the first place
1) Don't sign up for anything likely to get you automated messages unless they're essential
